title: LEX1/3: ELEXIS data model

author: Carole Tiberius, Information Technology Research Institute, University of Brighton

segmentation: OK, so my name is Carol Tiberius and I will talk about the Alexis data model, the Alexis Data model will form an important part of the Alexis infrastructure.
And um, yeah, I will start by.
Saying why we need this model?
Well, basically we find the reason for the need of a single data model already in the proposal where we say that we want to ensure that there's integration at even the most basic level.
And we will do this by defining a minimal common data model, capturing the basic concepts of lexicographic resource.
So the main reason why we need this data model in Elexis is because we want to be able to link the data reliably.
I guess it's self evident that the data is crucial for us.
Without data we will.
Well, we may have an infrastructure implemented, but the infrastructure will be empty, so then we won't be able to see the full potential of what elexis aims to achieve.
Actually, the amount of available data is not the issue for us already.
In the proposal, a number of potential data providers are mentioned.
Namely, data will be provided by the consortium partners by observing institutions, and we will take advantage of other Open Access resources that contain lexical graphic data.
That you can find in the claron and diarrhea repository.
Ice.
So just to give you an illustrator, an idea of the amount of data and the type of data that are going to be provided by the consortium partners.
I'm just going to show you a few tables.
Listing these resources.
So you can see that we have quite a variety of languages and also quite a variety of types of dictionaries that are going to be included.
Historical, contemporary, dialectal, multilingual, monolingual.
So the amount of data is not the problem, but the issue that we're facing is that.
The data comes from quite desperate lexicographic sources.
They have been compiled within national and regional projects and as such they are typically encoded in their own custom formats.
And as we also all know, standardization efforts have not been particularly successful in lexicography.
Before the digital age.
So Judy Pace will use this metaphor of the data silos.
Anna, you relax presentation of last year and I find it quite illustrative for the situation that we're facing.
We have standalone lexicographic resources.
And so more.
In particular, if we look at the data from the consortium partners, we see that we have data in XML.
That's mainly the counter and temporary dictionaries with data anti.
I mainly the retro digitized dictionaries as data in HTML.
Jason LD relational databases are used in an API as well.

And to be able to integrate all this data in the Alexis infrastructure, a set of common protocols has been defined in work package two in the past year and this figure shows the input side of the interface and the rest interface will be built in the second year of the project, so this year.
You can see that.
There's various access routes that are distinguished on the left hand side of this picture.
Namely, data can be contributed either STR like 0 or as until X lemon.
These are the two data formats that are supported by ELEXIS, and it can also be delivered by in XML or in any other format.
If the data is delivered as custom XML, then we will be able to take advantage of the conversion tool that seems already mentioned.
That converts custom XML into TRX O and those contributing data into their own format will have to implement the rest interface according to the specifications that will be provided by Elexis.
And then just a little bit about this.
Interoperability formats have sets with support data in until X, lemon and anti like 0.

So until X lemon probably familiar to most of the year, but maybe not all it's developed by the W 3C until the ontology Lexecon Community group and it provides a general framework for the representation of lexical information relative to ontologies, as well as providing for the general modeling of lexical graphs in terms of sensors.
And concepts in an approach that is inspired by the Princeton Wordnet model and until X Lemon is based on the resource description frame.

It's made up of a number of modules, five which have been around for a bit longer, and there's two which are currently in development and especially the lexicography module is probably of interest to us.
And.
Here for you just to show that this work has been ongoing for quite awhile.
It started in 2006.
Wrangling info work by Botola.

And now we are at the final until X specification in 2016, and I think you had John knows everything about until X lemon and he had an even more recent picture showing that the addition of the lexicography module, which is currently being developed.
The other format that we support, the I like 0 is more recent actually work start on TI like Zero started within the cost action.
the European network of Lexicography in the Working group to en retro digitized dictionaries.
After the cost action, it continued in diarrhea, working group, lexical resources, and at the moment also in Elexis.
So as more Matt has already said, it's a subset of the T schema.
And it serves us arrive at the baseline encoding and a target format to facilitate the interoperability of heterogeneously encoded lexical resource is.
And it should not.

Be thought of as a replacement of the dictionary chapter, but it should primarily be seen as a format that existing T dictionaries can be univocally transformed to in order to be queried, visualized, or mind in a uniform way, and also in the context of Alexis we have added to be linked.
So going back.
We have our common protocols, so now yeah, how can we integrate the data?
We have common protocols and this ensures what Nancy Aydan, Posti Owski called Syntactic Interoperability.
See.
And by this they mean that's relying on specified data formats, communication protocols and the like.
You ensure communication and data exchange.
So the systems that are involved can process the exchange information, but there's still no guarantee that the interpretation is the same.
However, as we rely on already onto interoperability format style XO an until X Lemon, I think the situation is not as.
But for us we have probably syntactic interoperability plus.
But still, this room for ambiguity because there's no guarantee that was labeled by acts in one resource, actually means the same thing as well as labeled by acts in the other resource.
So what we need?

It's in the context of Elexis is semantic interoperability, and as I deposit EOS key, define it again that exists when two systems have the ability to automatically interpret exchange information meaningfully and accurately in order to produce useful results via reference to a common information exchange reference model.
So how?
Are we going to achieve this within Elexis?
I think we need three things.
We need a common vocabulary.
We also need common metadata and as we're dealing with lexicographic data, which is often restricted, we also need a common licensing schema.
So let me start.
The common vocabulary Easter already pointed out that we did a survey.
The wishes and needs of lexicographers.
Survey for institutions, and one for lexicographers, and in the institutional one.
We had a separate section on meta data formats, etc and also a question about common vocabulary.
And yeah, as the responses show, the use of common vocabularies is not yet common practice within the consortium partners.
This is 11 consortium partners who completed the survey, so maybe we cannot generalize that much, but.
That's correct, yeah, it says something about situation within the can.
Solution So what we need to do and what we're going to do is we're going to establish a reference model where the main concepts are unambiguously defined and his main concept within Alexis.
We have identified a number about 15.

Concepts that are important to start with, and So what we're going to do is we're going to unambiguously define these, and to do that we're not going to reinvent the wheel, but we're going to rely on existing standards, so the ISO standards for lexicography, ISL 1951 and LMF, as well as on our elexis interoperability standards.
So basically, we're going to see we're going to take our terms that we think refers to these concepts that we have in mind for Alexis and that are important for Alexis.
And we're going to see how they are currently defined in ISO 1951 in LMF until X, Lemon tea elixir, and then we take a decision on.
OK, this is how we define this concept in.

The Alexis infrastructure and yes, in addition we will also recommend the use of standard vocabularies and for instance for part of speech we will recommend the use of the Universal dependencies tag set only at the top level.
And then to show you that that's needed, just an illustration of the current state of affairs.
Last year I asked for a number of samples from the different data that's going to be provided by the consortium, and in this sample data I tried to identify what we yeah, but I think.
Is the definition of these main concepts that we have in mind and you then see that at the current state of affairs is that.
Different resources use their own tag for.

To identify this information, so for Lema, it's still fairly straightforward to identify, and that in the different samples part of speech also, but quite often or especially in the retro digitized resource, as you see that it's not just the main part of speech category that's given, but often the features are grouped together in one glossas gets more difficult already.
Examples at the stations.
Do we consider concordance lines as examples?
And yes, the last one is even more complex, so we'll first define that, and then I'll talk about it again next year.
So then we look at the metadata.
The situation is fairly similar for the common vocabulary.
The survey for the institution shows that, meta data are not yet really used.
No an intended to have is the biggest share in this diagram, and the picture looks the same for the standard licensing scheme.
However, your 2 answers again, you can't really generalize, but.
There's still work to do for Alexis.

So the Alexis data model is then a minimal common data model which will capture the main concept of lexicographic resources and it will take into account international standards and it can be expressed by both interoperability formats until X, lemon and T like 0.
And the main goal to have this common data model is that we ensure semantic interoperability and enable the integration of various resources in the Alexis infrastructure.
Then let me conclude with just a simple use case scenario.
Suppose we have lexical graphic project acts and they say, well, we would like to contribute data to Alexis.
We have a monolingual Dictionary of contemporary Dutch with quite a complex microstructure.
So how does that work?
Well, Elexis says wonderful data.
Yes, the more the better.
But yeah, so someone has already said this.
Felt out this works to be able to integrate your data in the Alexis infrastructure.
You will have to map the labels that you use for the elements in your data onto the elexis data model.
And then for the Dutch case, it looks more or less like this.
It's easy to see all the Dutch words are have a red line under them.
And then you see that lemma form.
That's where the lemma stands.
Sparta speech information.
Of course, then we would have to normalize that to universal dependencies as well.
The sense level already becomes more tricky.
I've just put a line now to the broadest container, but this is probably not what Alexis wants.
So we need to refine that, and then it goes on.
And then once this is defined and you've provided the mapping, it can be integrated in the Alexis infrastructure.
And, as Seaman already said as well, you can.
And also get a copy back, NTI leg O.
That looks that more or less like this.
So where do we stand up?
That's what I just said, and what are we going to do in the rest of this year?
Well, most importantly, will have to define this common vocabulary for the main concept, so that's most urgent, and that's what we will do in the next couple of months.
And then for the rest of the year, we also have to make sure that these main concepts are implemented in TI, like 0 and Intalex Lemon.
And then thank you for your thank you.
